definitions: remove marks or writing by rubbing with an eraser or similar tool
remove information from computer memory or eliminate from conscious thought
examples: Please erase the whiteboard before the next class begins
She used an eraser to erase the pencil marks carefully
The computer virus erased all the important files from the system
He tried to erase the painful memories from his mind

definitions: construct a building or structure in an upright position from the ground up
raise something to an upright or vertical position from lying down
examples: The construction crew will erect the new office building downtown
They plan to erect a monument in the town square
The campers helped erect the tent before the storm arrived
Workers carefully erect the scaffolding around the construction site

definitions: gradually wear away soil or rock through natural forces like water or wind
slowly weaken or destroy something abstract like trust or confidence over time
examples: Heavy rains continue to erode the riverbank each spring season
Ocean waves slowly erode the cliff face year after year
Constant lies will erode trust between friends and family members
Poor customer service can erode a company's reputation over time

definitions: make a mistake or be incorrect in judgment action or belief
examples: To err is human but to forgive is divine
Even experienced doctors can err in their medical diagnoses sometimes

definitions: burst forth or break out suddenly and violently like a volcano exploding
suddenly express strong emotion especially anger in an uncontrolled way
examples: The volcano could erupt at any moment according to scientists
Lava and ash erupt from the mountain covering nearby villages
The crowd erupted in cheers when their team scored the goal
He tends to erupt in anger over small frustrations lately

definitions: increase rapidly in extent intensity or severity becoming more serious or extreme
examples: The conflict continues to escalate despite diplomatic efforts to resolve it
Costs can quickly escalate when renovating an old house without planning

definitions: deliberately avoid or abstain from something as a matter of principle or preference
examples: Many health-conscious people eschew processed foods in their daily diet
The artist chose to eschew modern technology in creating her work

definitions: accompany someone to protect guide or show courtesy especially on a journey
examples: Security guards will escort the celebrity through the crowded airport terminal
He offered to escort his elderly neighbor to her doctor's appointment

definitions: adopt or support a cause belief or way of life with dedication
marry someone in a formal ceremony according to traditional or legal customs
examples: The politician continues to espouse progressive environmental policies in speeches
Many young activists espouse the principles of social justice today
In medieval times nobles would espouse partners for political alliances
The ceremony where they espouse each other will be held tomorrow

definitions: catch sight of or glimpse something especially from a distance or unexpectedly
examples: From the hilltop we could espy the distant mountain range clearly
The sailor was first to espy land after weeks at sea

definitions: respect and admire someone greatly considering them to have worth or value
examples: Students esteem their teacher for her wisdom and patient guidance
The community continues to esteem him as an honest business leader

definitions: cause someone to be no longer close or affectionate to another person
examples: Years of bitter arguments finally estrange the two brothers completely
His selfish behavior will estrange him from his closest friends

definitions: cut or carve a design into a hard surface using acid or tools
fix something permanently in memory or mind through strong impression
examples: The artist will etch intricate patterns into the glass using acid
They decided to etch their initials into the old oak tree
The tragic event would etch itself into the nation's collective memory
Her kind words remain etched in my heart after all these years

definitions: remove people from a dangerous place to somewhere safer in an emergency
remove all contents from a container or empty something completely
examples: Authorities evacuate coastal residents before the hurricane makes landfall tonight
The fire alarm means we must evacuate the building immediately
The pump will evacuate all water from the flooded basement area
Doctors may need to evacuate fluid from the patient's lungs

definitions: escape or avoid something or someone by cleverness trickery or swift movement
examples: The criminal managed to evade police capture for several months successfully
She tries to evade difficult questions during the press conference

definitions: preach the Christian gospel to convert others to the faith actively
promote or advocate something enthusiastically like a cause or product
examples: Missionaries travel to remote villages to evangelize the local population
The preacher would evangelize on street corners every Sunday morning
Tech enthusiasts evangelize the benefits of artificial intelligence to businesses
She continues to evangelize healthy eating habits to her friends

definitions: turn from liquid into vapor when heated or exposed to air
gradually disappear or cease to exist like hopes or possibilities fading
examples: Water will evaporate quickly under the hot desert sun conditions
The morning dew will evaporate as the temperature rises today
His confidence seemed to evaporate when he faced the large audience
Their savings evaporate due to unexpected medical expenses this year

definitions: occur as a result or consequence of actions or circumstances eventually happening
examples: Poor planning will eventuate in project failure and wasted resources
Their long negotiations finally eventuate in a successful business partnership

definitions: legally force a tenant to leave a property usually for non-payment
examples: The landlord must evict tenants who haven't paid rent for months
The court order allows them to evict the family by month's end

definitions: bring or recall a feeling memory or image to the conscious mind powerfully
examples: The old photograph would evoke memories of childhood summers at grandma's house
Certain scents can evoke powerful emotions from our past experiences

definitions: make a problem bad situation or negative feeling worse or more severe
examples: Drinking alcohol will only exacerbate your headache and make you feel worse
His thoughtless comments exacerbate the tension between the two departments

definitions: represent something as being larger better or worse than it really is
examples: Children often exaggerate their achievements to impress their friends at school
Don't exaggerate the difficulty of the task to avoid doing it

definitions: remove earth carefully from an area to find buried objects or remains
make a hole or channel by digging especially for construction or archaeology
examples: Archaeologists carefully excavate the ancient burial site for historical artifacts
Workers excavate tons of soil to prepare the building's foundation
The team will excavate the area where they believe dinosaur fossils exist
Construction crews excavate a tunnel through the mountain for the highway

definitions: be exceptionally good at or proficient in an activity or subject area
examples: She continues to excel in mathematics winning several academic competitions this year
Athletes who excel at their sport often train for many hours daily

definitions: take a short extract from a text film or piece of music
examples: The teacher will excerpt key passages from the novel for class discussion
Publishers often excerpt chapters from new books to generate reader interest

definitions: cut out surgically especially removing diseased tissue from the body carefully
remove a section from a piece of writing during the editing process
examples: The surgeon will excise the tumor from the patient's lung tomorrow
Doctors must excise all infected tissue to prevent the spread
The editor decided to excise several paragraphs from the final manuscript
They had to excise sensitive information from the government report

definitions: cry out suddenly in surprise strong emotion or pain using emphatic speech
examples: She would exclaim with joy when she saw her test results
The children exclaim in wonder at the magician's amazing tricks

definitions: discharge waste matter from the body through natural biological processes
examples: The kidneys excrete waste products from the blood through urine production
Plants excrete oxygen as a byproduct of photosynthesis during daylight

definitions: be a typical example of something or represent it in a characteristic way
examples: Her dedication and hard work exemplify the company's core values perfectly
These ancient artifacts exemplify the artistic style of that historical period

definitions: free someone or something from an obligation or liability imposed on others
examples: The new law will exempt small businesses from certain tax requirements
Students with medical conditions may be exempt from physical education classes

definitions: apply or bring to bear a force influence or quality with effort
examples: You need to exert more pressure to open this stubborn jar lid
Parents often exert considerable influence on their children's career choices

definitions: breathe out air from the lungs through nose or mouth naturally
examples: Take a deep breath and slowly exhale to reduce stress levels
The doctor asked her to exhale completely before taking the x-ray

definitions: use up resources or supplies completely leaving nothing remaining or available
drain someone of their physical or mental energy making them very tired
examples: The long hike will exhaust our water supply before reaching camp
Don't exhaust all your savings on unnecessary luxury items now
The marathon race will exhaust even the fittest runners by the end
Taking care of twins can exhaust new parents very quickly

definitions: expel and bar someone from their native country typically for political reasons
examples: The government decided to exile the political dissident to a remote island
Many writers were forced to exile themselves during the oppressive regime

definitions: absolve someone from blame for a fault or wrongdoing especially after investigation
examples: New DNA evidence will exonerate the wrongly convicted man after twenty years
The investigation results exonerate her from any involvement in the scandal

definitions: drive out an evil spirit from a person or place through religious ceremony
examples: The priest attempted to exorcise demons from the possessed young woman
Ancient cultures would exorcise evil spirits using sacred rituals and prayers

definitions: send a person to live outside their native country often for work
examples: The company will expatriate several managers to their new Asian offices
Many professionals choose to expatriate themselves for better career opportunities

definitions: make an action or process happen sooner or be accomplished more quickly
examples: Please expedite the shipping of our order for the urgent deadline
The manager will expedite approval of your vacation request this week

definitions: force someone to leave a place especially a school or organization permanently
examples: The school board voted to expel students caught cheating on exams
Security guards will expel anyone who disrupts the concert from the venue

definitions: spend or use up a resource such as money energy or time completely
examples: Athletes expend enormous amounts of energy during intense training sessions daily
Don't expend all your effort on the first part of the project

definitions: come to the end of validity period like licenses or contracts ending
die or breathe one's last breath ceasing to live
examples: Your driver's license will expire next month so renew it soon
The warranty on this product will expire after one year
The patient quietly expired in her sleep at the hospice facility
He feared he would expire before seeing his grandchildren again

definitions: present and explain a theory or idea systematically and in great detail
examples: The professor will expound on quantum physics theories during today's lecture
She loves to expound her views on sustainable living to anyone listening

definitions: destroy completely especially killing all members of a group or species
examples: The pest control company will exterminate the termites infesting your house
Efforts to exterminate invasive species help protect native wildlife populations

definitions: cause a fire or light to stop burning by removing heat or oxygen
bring to an end completely destroying hope or possibility
examples: Firefighters work quickly to extinguish the blaze before it spreads further
Always extinguish campfires completely before leaving the camping site
Years of disappointment can extinguish even the brightest hopes and dreams
The new evidence will extinguish any doubts about her innocence

definitions: obtain something by force threats or other unfair means especially money
examples: The criminals tried to extort money from local business owners through threats
Corrupt officials often extort bribes from citizens seeking basic services

definitions: hand over a person accused of a crime to another jurisdiction for trial
examples: The country agreed to extradite the suspect to face charges abroad
International treaties determine when nations must extradite criminals to each other

definitions: extend the application of data to an unknown situation by inferring continuation
examples: Scientists extrapolate future climate patterns from current temperature data and trends
We can extrapolate next quarter's sales from this month's performance

definitions: free someone or something from a constraint or difficulty with effort
examples: Rescue workers carefully extricate victims from the collapsed building rubble
She managed to extricate herself from the awkward social situation gracefully

definitions: discharge moisture or smell slowly and steadily from pores or surface
display an emotion or quality strongly and openly in one's manner
examples: The pine trees exude sticky resin during the warm summer months
Fresh bread will exude an irresistible aroma throughout the bakery
She seems to exude confidence whenever she enters a room
The old mansion continues to exude an atmosphere of mystery

definitions: look at someone or something closely in a direct or rude way
examples: The security guard would eyeball every customer entering the jewelry store
Don't just eyeball the measurements when baking this delicate recipe
